column11: What single change would most increase your likelihood of using these security reports in your projects?
Security compliance requirements at my place of work. As far as the report itself, it is well done and useful.
Seeing examples of projects that have successfully used these reports would make me more confident in their reliability.
Adding prioritized remediation tasks with responsible owners and estimated effort would make the report immediately actionable and significantly increase the likelihood of using it in my projects.

This is a very technical report and it would be awesome if i could pass the programming language, framework etch i am using or i am going to use and have a recommendation of the implementation (libraries, design patterns etc) in Security Architecture chapter (9)

I would try to output this report as a .md file, which I would next try to feed it to an agent. Then I would proceed to either ask the agent about the report findings, or use his coding knowledge to help me code my project.
Maybe a format that'd be suitable to feed to Claude Code/Cursor so it can analyze the codebase and connect each report to the relevant parts in the code (when applicable)
A short summary with highlighted concerns
Better description of the Security Overview Dashboard figures (x and y axis descriptions, etc.) with an overview description.

The integration with our internal tools would make reports of these type very significant, especially if data from our project planning would automatically get pulled directly to the tool for my security report to get generated.

The report's AI/ML section provides good high-level threat identification and controls. For production implementation of multi-agent systems, add:

• Detailed model governance framework: versioning, artifact signing, CI/CD pipeline for models
• Concrete Prolog agent sandboxing: seccomp profiles, container isolation, resource limits, approval workflows for rule changes
• Implementation patterns: provenance tracking and confidence scoring in agent outputs
• Acceptance criteria: testable scenarios (e.g., 'model rollback <1hr', 'cross-tenant access impossible')
• Operational runbooks: detecting and responding to agent misbehavior and adversarial attacks
• Cloud-native deployment: Kubernetes pod policies, mTLS service mesh, immutable audit logging

These concrete patterns would enable direct implementation of agentic systems.
References to outside sources to help meet standard where knowledge is lacking.

The report uses a set of assumptions on the software architecture that relates to mostly "mainstream" software practices, which have their value, but not necessarily fit practices for small teams and startups (e.g. SPA, intergration with services with cloud providers). I think that these assumptions may be misleading in some circumstances, so the report should either not rely on this assumption or ask explicitly which approaches for software architecture the project is willing to use.

There could be a session combining (9.2) Required Controls, Recommended Patterns, (10.2) Phased Implementation Plan and (12.3) Detailed into some sort of table ranking the countermeasures and pointing to the threat. It is not about the report content, but about the form it is presented. Some sort of TLDR based on urgency.
